TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition, from 184 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders:

SPEECH.PARA: A group of citizens has joined together to express publicly their deep concern about the Federal Government plan to introduce the Australia Card. The Group is diverse in background, occupation and political belief.
Each of the persons who has signed this declaration sought to awaken in the public mind an awareness of the long-term dangers of the national identity card system as proposed.

It must be understood that the Australia Card is not simply an identification card system-it involves the collection, compilation, recording and assessment of information on the activities of every individual Australian.
This system has never before been proposed in a free country in the form and extent now proposed for Australia, indeed, the U.S.A. has specifically rejected a similar identification card scheme.

It is intrusive, expensive, inconvenient and will not fulfil the expectations of its proponents who propose to employ a further 2,000 civil servants and who say the system will run at a loss for four years. Neither the Federal Police not the Department of Social Security have supported the scheme.
In acting to bring in this system the Government is acting against the majority report of an all-Party Select Committee of Parliament.
It is beyond the Constitutional power of the Commonwealth to impose directly a requirement to have a card.

Although there are provisions which avoid imposing an obligation to apply for the Card, this means nothing when the Card must be used for all employment, banking, medical and property transactions. The simple act of taking or continuing a job will be unlawful without the card. (Penalty up to $20,000).

We express our deep concern that the Government proposes to require all Australians to establish identity through a national, centralised, computerised identification system which will additionally involve the collection of information about individual Australians, and the assessment and use of that information for Government purposes:
that it is effectively compulsory;
that it denies economic freedom;
that it invades privacy'

the effect of the Bill as proposed is that all Australians who wish to be employed or hold a bank or building society account must attend on the Government to be photographed and then prove their identity;
that to the number of dole cheats and social security frauds will be added the card forgers and duplicators;

that its principle impact will be on the lives of ordinary decent, honest Australians and the cost and inconvenience to government, business and individuals will far outweigh any potential revenue gains;

that it reverses the founding principle of a free society in that it makes the innocent individual accountable to the state, instead of the state being accountable to the collection of individuals in it;
that it assumes the benevolence of Government against the overwhelming historical evidence that individual liberty is only maintained through the control of the power of the state;
that future denial of the card will be a weapon available for the exercise of power over individuals, groups and those who disagree with the government of the time;
that the available alternatives to eliminate fraud against the revenue and the taxpayers should be considered and where appropriate pursued.

Those who have signed this Declaration have done so freely and to express their concern regardless of short-term political considerations, and invite others of like mind to join in signing and supporting this document.

AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION BILL 1987
Purpose of the Bill

Mr President, the purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the restructuring and reorganisation of the Australian Tourist Commission in line with the majority of the recommendations of the Report of the Australian Government Inquiry Into Tourism (the Kennedy report) which were endorsed by the Government in December 1986. The Commission was established in 1967 by the Australian Tourist Commission Act. This Act, now 20 years old, and amended on a number of occasions, is deficient in many ways and does not reflect current legislative drafting practices. It was therefore decided that rather than introduce substantial further amendments of the current Act, it would be desirable to introduce a new Bill which would reflect not only the recommendations of the Kennedy Report endorsed by the Government, but also take into account recent Government reforms concerning statutory authorities.
Background
On 19 January 1986 the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism announced the establishment of the Australian Government Inquiry Into Tourism.

The Inquiry was established in response to the rapid expansion of tourism in the previous 3 years and the industry's increasing importance to the Australian economy. In accordance with its terms of reference the Inquiry was principally concerned with the `effectiveness of Commonwealth administration of its tourism promotion functions and related issues.' In specific terms the Inquiry was asked to review:
* the appropriateness of existing provisions of the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967
* funding, contracting, and staffing arrangements and structures appropriate for achieving the Commonwealth's tourism promotion objectives
* relevant operational arrangement, services and systems of the Australian Tourist Commission
* relationships between the Australian Tourist Commission and Commonwealth, State and other organisations with responsibilities that impact on tourism
* future policies and strategies that might be adopted by the Commonwealth to achieve greater effectiveness in its tourism promotion activities overseas and in Australia
* any other matters referred to the Committee by the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism during the period of the review.

The inquiry was carried out by a committee of five. The Chairman was Mr Jim Kennedy, Deputy Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission and Deputy Chairman of the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation. Other members were Mr John Donohoe, Chairman of the Tourist Commission of New South Wales; Ms Geraldine Paton, Publisher of the Australian; Mr Thomas Derry, General Marketing Manager, Ansett Airlines; and Mr Emanuel Klein, then Senior Private Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

I would like to place on record at this point the Government's sincere appreciation for the untiring work of the Committee, whose members freely gave a vast amount of their own time to carry out the most thorough investigation ever undertaken into tourism in this country. The 96 recommendations of the Committee's Report were supported by a most comprehensively documented report. The Report was produced after wide consultation with the industry and State and Territory Government authorities. The large number of detailed submissions and comments received by the Committee from industry and Government bodies also reflected the growing importance of this industry's place in the Australian economy.

On the 7th of May this year the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism outlined to the House of Representatives the contribution of tourism to the economy. In doing so the Minister detailed the spectacular growth in the last five years which is due in no small part to the solid backing the industry has received from this Government and in particular the support we have given to the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission.

I do not propose to repeat in detail the areas in which this Government has laid the foundations to make this industry the fastest growing industry in Australia. Suffice to say that our achievements, spearheaded by the more than trebling of funding of the Australian Tourist Commission from $10m to over $33m. Easing of foreign investment guidelines, and encouragement of career training of people for the industry, to mention just three areas of progressive Government initiatives, have greatly assisted the tourism industry to move into its current dynamic mode.

The recommendations of the Kennedy report, most of which were adopted by the Government, will make the Australian Tourist Commission a much leaner and more commercially-orientated organisation with greater emphasis on marketing, planning and evaluation.
This Bill provides for a new legislative base on which the Australian Tourist Commission will meet the exciting challenges of the future to make Australia a premier international Tourist destination.
Major features of the Bill
I will now turn to the major features of this Bill.
The function of the Commission
The principal object of this Bill is to restructure the Australian Tourist Commission to enable it to perform its functions more effectively.

This Bill will provide a new focus for the Commission and will update the Commission's purpose and operating methods. This will act as an important lever for development of tourism in Australia and enable the Commonwealth to obtain the best return on the resources it has allocated for this purpose.

Under this Bill, the scope of the corporate mission of the Commission will be narrowed. The major thrust of the Commission's activity will now be towards promoting Australia as an attractive tourist destination in the international market place. It will withdraw from the field of promotion of domestic tourism, leaving that to the States and Territories. The Commission will, however, retain a role in enhancing the awareness of the importance of tourism to Australia.

The development of tourism in Australia in relation to the inbound market requires specific planning and it is not proposed that the Commonwealth proceed down this track in isolation. We will be seeking the co-operation of all concerned. But it needs to be emphasised that rationalisation of the amount of money spent overseas by governments and industry is required to maximise the effects of those resources for the benefit of Australia's economy overall.
Accordingly, the principal objects of the Commission are:
(a) to increase the number of visitors to Australia from overseas; and
(b) to maximise the benefits to Australia from overseas visitors.
In order to achieve this the Commission's functions as set out in the Bill are:
* to promote Australia overseas as a tourist destination
* to enhance awareness of Australia overseas as a tourist destination
* to co-ordinate the overseas promotional efforts of the Australian tourism industry, in co-operation with State and Territory tourism authorities and with the Australian tourism industry; and
* to enhance awareness in Australia of the Australian tourism industry.
Structure of the Board and Appointment of Members

This Bill provides for a Board of Directors of the Australian Tourist Commission to consist of a Chairperson, Deputy Chairperson, a government member, who will be an officer of the Australian Public Service, a Managing Director and 5 other members. This provides for a Board of nine members as opposed to 13 members under the existing legislation. This is in line with Government statutory authority reforms requiring that boards be streamlined to a workable size.

The Kennedy Report found that the current Board of 13 did not encourage efficient operations. In fact, a number of submissions, including that of the Commission itself, advocated a smaller Board. The Government's reforms to statutory authorities also express a desire for statutory board appointments to be people with the skills and experience best suited to guiding the business of the particular enterprise at the highest possible level.

A number of submissions to the Inquiry reflected the desire to restructure representation on the Board including the statutory requirement for representatives from the States and Territories to sit on the Board on a rotational basis. The States themselves criticised the current rotational system, particularly on the basis that they were disadvantaged when not participating on the Commission Board and did not have ready access to agenda papers for meetings and current market intelligence.
It would be impractical to have simultaneous representation of all States and Territories on the Board. This Bill removes the current formalised State representation on the Board.
However, close consultations with the States is essential to the operations of the Commission and alternative and more effective consultative mechanisms are now being developed and implemented.

The Bill retains the existing provision for the appointment of a Board member from the Australian Public Service, now referred to as the government member. It is appropriate that the Board continues to have the facility to draw on knowledge and understanding of public administration and statutory accountability requirements, and Government policy.

The Bill provides for the appointment of the Chairperson on a part-time or full-time basis. At present it is considered appropriate for a Chairperson to be appointed on a part-time basis. However, should circumstances dictate at some future time that it would be more appropriate to appoint a full-time Chairperson, the Bill does provide that flexibility.

Accordingly, and in line with the Report recommendations endorsed by the Government the Bill provides for the Board members to be appointed by virtue of their individual skills, expertise and experience relevant to the tourism industry, rather than as representatives of associations, States, Territories or other bodies which may have particular tourism interests. It is also envisaged that a Board appointee will have extensive commercial experience at a senior level, and have a demonstrated track record of successful management.
Corporate Planning and Accountability

A major focus included in this Bill which affects the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission, and an important area not covered under its existing legislation, concerns corporate planning and accountability as set out in Part IV of the Bill.

The Kennedy Inquiry examined in detail and made a number of recommendations relating to an appropriate management framework for the Commission. Their Report stressed that adequate evaluation of marketing and operational programs is essential. The analogy was drawn that just as all elements of Australian tourism should responsibly carry on their tourism business within a strategic, co-ordinated framework, the same principle must apply to the Australian Tourist Commission. It is now intended that the Board of the Commission become more active in the establishment of corporate goals of performance. The setting of corporate priorities to enhance the strategic planning process, and in the use of its available resources.

Section 25 of the Bill requires the Board to prepare a Corporate Plan. The Corporate Plan will include a statement of objectives of the Board and an assessment of the market and economic outlook for inbound tourism to Australia. The plan will span a rolling 5 year period and will be subject to review and revision each year. It will be submitted to the Minister for approval as soon as practicable after it is prepared.

The Corporate Plan will provide the basis of accountability to the Parliament and the industry at large of the Commission's activities and is in accordance with the Government's reforms for statutory authorities. In addition to the preparation of a Corporate Plan. Section 26 of this Bill provides for the Board to prepare an annual Operational Plan.

The Annual Operational Plan for a financial year will contain an estimate of the Commission's receipts and expenditure and specify the programs that the Board proposes to carry out and the resources that it proposes to allocate to each such program giving effect to the corporate plan for that year. Division 2 of Part IV of the Bill details the accountability of the Commission. It sets out the requirement for the Commission to prepare an Annual Report and also empowers the Minister in exceptional circumstances to give directions to the Board. It is included in accordance with standard and accepted legislative practice.
The Future

This Bill, the Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987, provides a new and comprehensive legislative base for the Australian Tourist Commission to equip it to successfully meet the growth and the challenges of a dynamic tourism industry up to and into the Twenty-first Century. It is appropriate that the legislation under which the Commission has so ably performed for the last twenty years should now be replaced with new and amended legislation which more adequately provides for the future operation and direction of the Commission. These legislative changes are the result of this Government's initiative to commission a far reaching inquiry to examine the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission. On the advice received from the Kennedy Committee of Inquiry. The Government has been able to formulate this Bill confident that it will provide the legislative basis for an efficient and effective Australian Tourist Commission.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

The purpose of this Bill is to enable the existing Managing Director of the Australian Tourist Commission to continue in office in accordance with the terms and conditions of his original appointment and to repeal existing Acts to allow the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987 to come into effect. —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs and relates to the failure by some electors to vote at the recent Commonwealth election. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many people would be aware that the Australian Electoral Commission is now computerised in its notification of voters who do not appear to have voted. Regrettably, in some divisions too many Australians have received notices from the Electoral Commission that they have not voted. Mistakes of this sort will always occur but we are not particularly happy about the level of those mistakes on this occasion. It appears that, for the first time ever, the Electoral Commission has used electronic scanners of the roll to determine who has and who has not voted. There have been two problems related to the use of electronic scanners. Firstly, some of the polling clerks did not use the correct pen with which to mark off the voters. Secondly, certain blips have occurred within the computer.
—Perhaps we won the election after all. Can we have another election?

—I assure Senator Chaney that if these mistakes had not occurred our margin would have been even bigger. I think most honourable senators would understand that when we are using electronic scanners to scan 10 million names some mistakes will occur. The mistakes on this occasion were greater than I would regard as acceptable. The answer to that problem will be, firstly, more intensive training of polling officials to make sure they mark the roll off in a correct manner and, secondly, further refining of the electronic scanners.

ANSWER.PARA: I think everyone would concede that it is far cheaper to use electronic scanners than manually to check 10 million names after an election. I am sure that the divisional returning officers will accept the explanation from those who have been sent notices in error that they have already voted. There is a tearoff post-back section in the demand sent by the electoral office asking why people failed to vote. The explanation that a person has voted would be sufficient for the Australian Electoral Commission to take no further action.

I have had several letters from people who did vote and who have received one of these failure to vote notices. I could imagine nothing more irritating for a citizen than to have done his duty and then to be accused of not having done it. Everyone in this chamber would know that the hardest thing even in politics is to be accused of something when one is not guilty of it. That is always hard to defend. These problems with the electronic scanners we hope to have rectified by the time of the next election. It would be a very expensive process to exercise the option to go back to the old system. The divisional returning officers are aware of the problems and have been instructed to deal with the matter with sympathy.

If it has already done so I have not yet seen it. As I said, I have been away. I will undertake to check in the next few days to see whether such a submission has arrived. The Government will obviously consider any request that it receives and I will notify the Senate in due course of the results of those considerations.

ANSWER.PARA: As for giving unequivocal undertakings about being bound by the Helsham inquiry, obviously the Government would not set up an inquiry of this stature unless it regarded it with great seriousness. I am satisfied that this inquiry will produce a result that will have come about only after considerable study by, I think, an impartial and obviously capable team. At the end of that inquiry, as with any inquiry on any other matter, the Government will consider its recommendations. I do not believe that there will be a need for another inquiry but I think we will wait to see the recommendations before we consider ourselves absolutely bound by all or any of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Home Affairs inform the Senate as to whether there will be a general redistribution of electoral boundaries before the next Federal election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the best things about being a senator, of course, is that our boundaries are not often redistributed. Three conditions are laid down in the Commonwealth Electoral Act that provide for a redistribution. Firstly, according to the Act, there will be a redistribution every seven years and, as the last redistribution occurred in 1984, on that general premise the next one will be in 1991. The Act also provides for a redistribution if more than one-third of electorates go outside the 10 per cent quota constraint. From memory, at the last Federal election only one electorate out of 148 was outside that 10 per cent variance. The way the trend lines are going for growth and decline it is very unlikely that more than two, three or four electorates Australia-wide will be outside the 10 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, a third provision in the Electoral Act reflects the constraints on the distribution of electoral boundaries by the Constitution; that is, that seats will be distributed according to the population of the States. Under these circumstances there will be at least one redistribution before the next Federal election. Victoria currently has 39 seats. That number will be reduced to 38 before the next Federal election can occur. I am not particularly good at reading demographic projections but I do not think there is any possibility of Victoria retaining 39 seats at the next election. However, it is much harder to predict the future of other States. There is a very outside possibility that Queensland could be granted an extra seat but, as I say, that is very unlikely. It is more likely that an extra seat will be granted to Western Australia. When the Australian Statistician reports next June, Western Australia will be very close to achieving a fourteenth seat. If the representation is implemented into legislation, as recommended by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, it may well be that the Australian Capital Territory will have an extra seat. I see that Senator Reid has put up her hand for endorsement already. Fred Chaney is already on the phone instructing his staff to draw up a proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would want the better half of Fremantle.

—Senator Chaney suggests that he would want the better half of Fremantle. So almost certainly there will be a prospective Federal redistribution in Victoria; a possible one in Western Australia; an outside chance in Queensland; and a fairly good chance in the Australian Capital Territory. Of course, this will cause a lot of tension in the other place and there will be a lot of map drawing, et cetera. I can say one thing about a prospective redistribution: like nearly every Federal redistribution in the past, it will be done impartially and fairly.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator MacGibbon might interject but we have had this out before. He has never produced one piece of evidence, and nor could he, to prove that a Federal redistribution has in any way been questionable. If a redistribution were required in Vic- toria or those other States it would be held in the latter part of 1988 and new boundaries would probably be promulgated some time around February-March 1989.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training by referring to the Commonwealth's assistance to government and non-government schools through the general recurrent grants program. I remind the Minister that, when the Government announced a new eight-year program in 1984, it promised to review the scheme in 1988-the year in which legislation covering the first four years of the scheme expires. In view of concern in the education community at the decline in Commonwealth participation in schools education through the specific purpose programs of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, will this review of the complementary recurrent scheme, administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, still take place? If so, what will be its ambit and will the reviewing body include representatives of school systems as well as parent and teacher groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines's question referred to the eight-year recurrent funding plan, four years of which was in legislation, providing per capita increases to government and non-government schools. This scheme is one which was universally admired and accepted by schools and school representatives throughout Australia as the most progressive decision ever made by a Commonwealth government in regard to schools funding. It was a plan that gave unprecedented security, particularly to the non-government school sector, enabling schools to plan in the long term for curriculum development, employment of teachers and so forth. Undoubtedly it was the major achievement of the previous Hawke Government in that it settled once and for all the state aid debate and gave all schools security in their future planning.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the recurrent scheme is separate from the specific purposes program. I do not think it is really accurate to describe the schemes as complementary. They are both Commonwealth programs, they are both aimed at raising standards and increasing opportunities in government and non-government schools, but they do serve different purposes. As was announced prior to the last election, there will be a review of the eight-year recurrent scheme now that nearly four years of that scheme are in place. That review will be conducted by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Of course, there will be the normal very intensive consultations with, and opportunity for participation by, all interested groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I would like the Minister to expand on the term `intensive consultations' and to tell me, in answer to the last part of the question, whether in fact the ambit of discussions will be wide, whether those extensive consultations will include parent and teacher groups as well as representatives of school systems, and how in fact those consultations will take place.

—It is the normal practice of the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training to hold regular consultations with all parent bodies and all teacher representative bodies and with State Ministers for education and representatives of State departments of education. It is normal practice also to hold consultations with special interest groups such as Aboriginal education groups, through the National Aboriginal Education Committee, groups with a particular interest in migrant education, and so on. Those consultations are a continual part of the Government's development of schools policy. All groups will have an opportunity to make submissions to the Department on the review. The actual scope of the review is still being developed within the Minister's Department. Certainly that review will be adequate to give the Government direction for the next four years of the scheme.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance, who represents the Treasurer. I ask: If the National Party of Australia 1987 election tax rate scale applied instead of the present tax rate scale, what would be the reduction in tax liability of, firstly, an Australian Capital Territory doctor if the doctors union succeeded in its 69 per cent pay claim and, secondly, a retired departmental secretary who was elected to Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ACT branch of the doctors union- -

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I suggest that this is not a proper use of Question Time and that the question is not in order. It has nothing to do with the Minister's responsibility. One could ask endless questions about the policies of this or that. I simply say that this is nothing to do with the administration of this Government at all. It is no more that the use of Question Time for political game play.
—I will allow the question. I think it does deal with the Minister's area of responsibility. However, I will listen carefully to the answer.

—Quite so, Mr President. The answer will be directly relevant to the question. I will answer it in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer, who, of course, has responsibility for the tax rate scale and taxation in general. As I think everybody knows, the ACT branch of the doctors union for some time has been conducting an industrial campaign based on work bans in pursuit of a claim for a 69 per cent pay increase-I repeat, a 69 per cent pay increase. Originally, the doctors were pursuing an 85 per cent pay increase. The doctors union has now modified its claim to a 69 per cent pay increase. Incidentally, it is a campaign which has the support of the Opposition. If the Australian Capital Territory doctors union were to succeed--
—How does it have the support of the Opposition?
—I have heard the honourable senator say that he supports it. If Senator Lewis does not support it, I would certainly welcome--
—That is an absolute lie.

—I am glad Senator Lewis does not support it. That is a different song from the one he was singing a couple of months ago. If the doctors were to succeed in their claim, they would receive, on average, an extra $20,000 income.
—How much?

—They would receive an extra $20,000 income on average. Some doctors would receive very much less than that and others would receive a great deal more but that is the average figure. The National Party's taxation policy, presented by Senator Stone prior to the election, contained what was called a bonus for working whereby any increase in income in this financial year, compared with that of the previous financial year, would be taxed at a rate of only 23 per cent. If the Australian Capital Territory doctors had succeeded in their pay claim and the National Party's tax policy had applied, assuming that doctors had incomes of at least $35,000, the average saving would have been $5,400. Their after tax income would have increased by $5,400. There would also have been some lesser benefits from a lower tax rate on income below $35,000, but that is relatively unimportant.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of a former departmental secretary in receipt of a Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension of $35,000 a year, who also became entitled to a parliamentary salary on round figures of $46,000 a year, if there were no other changes his after tax income would have been increased by more than $12,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Clearly, the answer is getting into the hypothetical. The Minister is putting forward a series of `ifs' in his response. Standing order 99 clearly provides that a senator is not entitled to ask a question which contains hypothetical matter. The same standing order says that we are not allowed to ask for an expression of opinion, a statement of government policy or a legal opinion. We cannot refer to debates in the current session or proceedings in committee not reported to the Senate. I make those points because the Standing Orders are meaningless if standing order 99 does not provide a guide for what questions are supposed to be restricted to. Quite clearly, all the Minister is doing is making up a series of hypotheticals and having a nice little debate with himself, as is his custom. Mr President, I suggest that he is clearly out of order in responding to the question he was asked.
—I uphold the point of order. I think Senator Walsh was dealing with a series of hypothetical questions. It was not in order to say what might happen under another administration.

—On the point of order, Mr President: far from being hypothetical, the case I am describing refers to Senator Stone. It would not have been a bonus for working but the result of a successful piece of double dipping.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Either the Minister must dissent from your ruling or he should be sat down.
—I will allow the Minister to answer the question. I have upheld the point of order that was taken by Senator Chaney. If Senator Walsh has anything to add to his answer, he can add it.

—I have given the figures, Mr President. The only other thing I have to add is that the essentially fraudulent nature of the National Party's bonus for working policy is revealed by the fact that the doctors would have gained not from working harder but by using industrial muscle to exploit the public and taxpayers. In the latter case, that of a departmental secretary, the gain would have been a function not of working harder but of a spectacularly successful piece of double dipping.

I note, for the benefit of the Minister receiving the question, the concern expressed by his colleague about the use of industrial muscle to obtain increases outside the wage fixing principles. Is the Minister aware of the settlement which followed the recent protracted strike on the North West Shelf project? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note on the North West Shelf issue from the Minister for Industrial Relations, to which I will refer in a moment. Before doing so, I make it quite clear that Senator Walsh's comments about the doctors union, as he calls it, in the ACTU--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —If the doctors union were in the ACTU, it would be much more responsible than it is now because the Australian Council of Trade Unions has been eminently responsible in respect of wage claims. —I am asking you whether you are levelling the playing field.

—I understand what the honourable senator is saying. It is a good school debating point but the reality is that that is the way Senator Walsh was answering the question. —It is an agreement.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. What progress has been made in regard to the participation of women in local government, both as elected representatives and as employees?
—Out comes the dorothy dix.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for her question and I assure Opposition senators that a great many women in the community are interested in the answer, even if, as we know, Opposition senators are not. The Commonwealth fully supports the principle of equal employment opportunity for women in local government and is encouraging developments at the local level in a number of ways. Through the Office of Local Government it has improved liaison with the Australian Local Government Women's Association, which is, for instance, represented on the judging panel for the National Awards for Innovation in Local Government. Taken with the Australian Centre for Local Government Studies, it is a means of improving women's participation in the courses provided.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has provided financial support to the New South Wales Department of Local Government, which is piloting an equal employment opportunity program in five councils, at a cost of $40,000. It has sponsored an analysis of women's employment within local government, which is being undertaken by the Municipal Officers Association, at a cost of $47,000. The Commonwealth has also provided support for the documentation of the role of women in local government, including a grant for the publication of a very interesting book, which I am sure Senator Vanstone should obtain a copy of, called Getting the Numbers. It was prepared by the Municipal Association of Victoria and identifies the reasons for the under-representation of women elected representatives. It is also looking at ways of encouraging more women to stand for office. The Local Government Ministers Conference resolved in principle last year to move towards the establishment of equal employment opportunity in Australian local government. It has included equal employment opportunity matters in the National Review of Local Government Labour Markets, undertaken under the auspices of that Conference.

There are some obvious examples of just how ably women are represented at the local government level throughout Australia. Indeed, there are three ministerial representatives, including the Hon. Barbara Wiese, the Minister for Local Government in South Australia, and the Hon. Janice Crosio, the Minister for Local Government in New South Wales. Furthermore, in Brisbane-the largest city council in the country-Sallyanne Atkinson is Mayor. Lecki Ord has just been elected to an equally important role as Mayor of the City of Melbourne. Whilst in Adelaide recently, I met a number of women mayors from South Australia. I can assure Senator Giles that women are indeed participating very effectively at all levels of local government and my Department will continue to support this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Reynolds to table the answer from which she has been reading on the ground that she said that everybody was interested in it.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—I will be happy to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer him to the set of documents which he tabled in the Senate on 24 September and which, as he said in his tabling statement, `relate to the tender application by Amann Aviation Pty Ltd for the Coastwatch contract and the consideration of that tender up to the time of the awarding of the contract on 13 March 1987', together with some other documents which are not relevant to my question. Is it not a fact that there were variations of that contract after the letter of acceptance of tender on 13 March 1987? I refer particularly to the change of aircraft. If I am right in believing that there were documents which related to a variation of the contract after 13 March, will the Minister table any subsequent documents which may be relevant to determining the full terms of the contract?

—There were a number of subsequent variations to the contract accomplished by exchanges of correspondence in the period after March and extending some number of months thereafter. Some of that correspondence and contract variation did, as I recall, relate to the question of the change of aircraft type. There is no secret about any of that nor any desire to withhold documents. As I explained to the Senate when I tabled the documents, that was the only bundle of documents that the Department at that stage had had time to work through in the context of applying freedom of information (FOI) standards in relation to issues such as commercial confidentiality. There were some subsequent documents which had been specifically pulled out for other purposes and had been worked through. I am perfectly prepared to make those other documents available when the process of FOI scrutiny is complete and I would have thought the appropriate place to make them available was to the Senate committee looking at this question. I am perfectly happy to make the documents available to that committee as soon as that task is complete.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, relates to the Queensland Cane Growers Council. Does this Council represent a form of compulsory unionism? Is it a fact that the money levied from smaller cane growers supporting the Australian Labor Party (ALP) was passed on by the Queensland Cane Growers Council to the National Farmers Federation for use in its anti-ALP campaigning in the recent Federal election? Is such a party political use of the Council's funds contrary to the Council's constitution? What will the Federal Government do to halt this disgraceful state of affairs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland Cane Growers Council was established at some time during the 1920s. Both the Council and its subsidiary bodies are funded by a levy on cane growers, based on the tonnage of cane delivered to mills. The levy is compulsory, and to the best of my knowledge there is no provision for conscientious objection to paying that levy as there is in a number of other awards, if not most industrial awards. In other words, it is a form of compulsory unionism-there is no question about that-and there is no conscientious objection clause as there is in most or many industrial awards. It certainly would be regarded, I suspect, as compulsory unionism by the H. R. Nicholls Society.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that the Queensland Cane Gro-wers Council did pass on money to the National Farmers Federation which it used in its specta-cularly unsuccessful anti-Labor Party campaign during the recent election. I will ask Mr Kerin to check that. If that is the case, and I believe it is, it could be regarded as part of that web of corruption which enmeshes the State of Queensland but which escapes Senator Stone's highly selective indignation, both in his capacity as a National Party senator for Queensland and as President of the H. R. Nicholls Society. I understand that the Council's constitution is supposed to preclude it from taking part in party political activity. If indeed money was passed on to the National Farmers Federation, certainly the spirit if not the letter of that constitution would have been breached.

In regard to what the Commonwealth Go-vernment can do about it, I will ask Mr Kerin to check to see whether, given the compulsory nature of this particularly rigid form of compulsory unionism which exists in Queensland for cane growers and is funded by a levy on production, that could be regarded as an excise, and therefore within the legal and constitutional jurisdiction of the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Justice in his capacity as Minister administering the Attorney-General's Department. Is the Minister aware that the Australian Federal Police Association has estimated fraud against the Commonwealth to be at least $11 billion? I refer the Minister to the statement on page 25 of the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth tabled in this Parliament recently:

QUESTION.PARA: It follows from lack of accurate and timely information that the Commonwealth cannot be sure that it is devoting adequate resources to dealing with fraud.
Without a clear picture of the scale and nature of fraud, it is, of course, difficult to assess the adequacy of resources deployed to deter, prevent, investigate or otherwise deal with it.

Is the Minister aware that the Australian Federal Police officers who are tasked with investigating Commonwealth fraud are grossly overworked and have been for a long time? Will the Government now establish an inquiry into the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth so that, in the words of the Review, the Australian public will be able to `assess the adequacy of resources deployed to deter, prevent, investigate' the level of fraud against the Commonwealth of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of certain claims that have been made, particularly during the latter stage of the election campaign, by the Australian Federal Police Association as to the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth. Despite a meeting I have held with Mr Chris Eaton, the Secretary of the Australian Federal Police Association, since the election and in anticipation of my addressing its council, I think next Monday, no evidence to substantiate that claim made by that Association in various Press releases and other media contexts has been forwarded to my office. Quite frankly, the quantities of money said to have been involved have varied so much that I am not quite clear whether the Australian Federal Police Association itself would stand by any particular figure that it has bandied about in the public domain. So, whilst I am aware of certain claims made, certainly no advantage has been taken of opportunities in face to face discussion with me by the Secretary of that Association to substantiate them.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very pleased that Senator Lewis raised at Question Time the very excellent report entitled Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth. To my mind, it represents-certainly for the first time so extensively-a realisation by a Federal government in this country that it needs to get its own house in order to deal with fraud which may be affecting the operations of a whole range of departments. That is why the review was undertaken at a very high level, by departmental secretaries-it is not just an ordinary inter-departmental committee-drawn, I think, from 11 departments. The main objective was to try to put in place those very mechanisms which, I agree with Senator Lewis, need to be put in place to enable those agencies to become more aware themselves of the steps they might take to detect fraud being practised against them and, having detected it, to deal with it. We need to have a more preventive regime rather than, as has been the case, agencies such as those for which I am responsible, for instance, the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions, and prosecution and court resources being tied up in the consequences downstream which could have been prevented by more vigilance by the upstream agencies.

A classic example of that relates to social security fraud. Many thousands of police hours were consumed in this area when, as I recall, social security payments were made by way of cheque to the household letter-boxes of recipients. There were many allegations of theft on the one hand and of persons coming to the counter of Department of Social Security offices claiming that the cheque had not been received and receiving emergency payments. There was a tremendous scope for an overburdening of Federal Police resources which has been largely obviated by the direct payment into accounts of social security payments. That is a very good example of steps being taken upstream in the agencies of the Commonwealth to prevent the overburdening and overwhelming of the downstream police, prosecution and court resources for which we have to make provision.

So I regard the steps already undertaken-the steps foreshadowed in this report-as being part of that process of getting that timely and effective action which will prevent fraud against the Commonwealth across a whole range of departments. Insofar as the report indicates that steps need to be taken and systems put in place, honourable senators will recall that there was also an announcement that a fraud control committee is to be established by the Government which, amongst other things, will transfer a lot of the expertise from those departments that already have a fair degree of it, such as the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security, to those departments which perhaps do not have these systems in place. I believe the overall effort by the Commonwealth-a continuing effort under the aegis of this fraud control committee-will ensure that the sorts of fraud that may have been occurring will be prevented or, if not prevented, detected very early.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots has warned that safety could be compromised by new arrangements for the control of flight standards? Is there any justification for this fear?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Federation of Air Pilots has expressed some concerns about the proposed incorporation of the flight standards function-which means essentially the licensing of aircraft and air crew-into the proposed new Civil Aviation Authority. It is a matter which I had discussed with the Federation prior to the making of the statement yesterday. It is also a matter on which I have undertaken to consult further before the decision is implemented. Nonetheless, I do not believe there is any justification whatever for the concern that has been expressed.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in the detailed statement which was tabled yesterday, I believe that there is strong logic in the view that the task of regulating aviation safety must be regarded as an integrated system in which all elements are co-ordinated to achieve maximum reliability and effectiveness. The operation of air traffic control and the flight advisory service, both of which are functions uncontroversially proposed to be vested in the Civil Aviation Authority, are as much a part of safety regulation as the regulation of aircraft and their crew. The two areas complement each other. I am sure that the Public Service officers who have made such a splendid contribution to our aviation safety in the context of hitherto integrated safety and operational functions within the Department will continue to play that role in the new authority when it is established in some 12 to 18 months time.

It is also to be noted in this respect that the United Kingdom's Civil Aviation Authority has very successfully combined safety regulation with the operation of the airways system. The United Kingdom decision was taken after a formal review-the Edwards Committee-and on the basis that the setting of standards, regulatory control and the day to day operation of the system should be under single control in the interests of efficiency and effectiveness, because of the close interrelationship involved.

I made it clear yesterday, and I do so again today, that the Australian Civil Aviation Authority will be required to give primacy to safety considerations over commercial ones, notwithstanding the apparent objections of the Business Regulation Review Unit (BRRU) to that course. With enemies such as the BRRU, who needs friends? The enabling legislation will make provision for the Minister to give broad directions in relation to the safety regulatory role to ensure that that occurs. I should also mention that the name of the proposed authority has been deliberately changed from the original proposal-the Civil Aviation Corporation-as another way of reflecting and demonstrating that safety priority whenever commercial considerations and safety ones potentially come into conflict. I think that that emphasis on the primacy of safety in the context of the new authority, together with the other explanation I have given about the integrated way in which these functions operate, will satisfy the basic concerns which have been expressed by the Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that a review of the defence service home loans scheme was announced in May 1985 and that in answer to my question on 25 March 1987 the then Minister said that the results were with the ministry and a determination would be made by Cabinet and announced to the public. Has the determination yet been made? When will the results be made public?
—I thank Senator Newman for her question. I know that she has an abiding interest in this issue. I will consult my colleague. I ask the honourable senator to treat this as a question on notice.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that Senator Gietzelt, in answering that question, told the Senate that, among other things, the purpose of the review was to make additional funds available to applicants. Can the Minister tell us whether the proposals announced in the Budget will achieve that objective?
—I have nothing further to add in response to Senator Newman's supplementary question. I will seek a response from Mr Humphreys.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of a decision handed down yesterday in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which will significantly increase the pay rates of an estimated 60,000 outworkers in the clothing trades? What, in the Minister's view, will be the effect of these changes on the costs and competitiveness of the Australian textile and clothing sector?

—Insofar as the decision will significantly raise pay rates for outworkers in the clothing industry, it will reduce the international competitiveness of that section of the industry. However, I am not sure that that is a bad thing. One never wants to see competitiveness reduced; on the other hand, one does not want to see, in the terms of what was said by the Deputy President of the Arbitration Commission, a continuation of virtual sweated labour in some sectors of the textile and clothing industry. The results of the decision will almost certainly be to raise the pay of outworkers in the industry, most of whom are migrant women.
—Most of them still have jobs.

—Yes, Senator, they still have jobs. So do people in Taiwan who get pay rates like these. I do not think that the changes in pay and conditions will be damaging to the long term future of the industry. Labour costs in some sectors of the industry will rise significantly, especially where there is a high dependence on low paid outworkers and some types of manufacture will be less viable in the medium to long term. However, I make the general point about this industry that these types of manufacture, low value added activities, do not or should not have a long term future in Australia in an industry such as this. Industry has to recognise that its long term viability and success are dependent on a greater shift into higher value added manufacture, particularly in further processing of natural fibres such as cotton and wool. No industry can be sustained in the longer term on the extraordinarily low pay rates paid to outworkers prior to this new decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. While labour costs certainly need to be kept in line with those of our trading partners, this should not perpetuate continuation of the sorts of rates which are being paid to, essentially, women migrant outworkers in the major cities of Australia in the clothing trades industry.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Would the Minister consider that the endorsement of the fine work of the Aborigi-nal Training and Cultural Institute that was given in the June issue of the Aboriginal Employment News, published by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, is an indictment of the decision of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to cease funding the Institute? Will the Minister ensure that funding for the Aboriginal Training and Cultural Institute in Sydney is resumed as soon as possible?
—I will have to take that question on notice and refer it for an early response to the Minister, Mr Gerry Hand.

—I ask the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health whether she is aware of recent criticisms of the operation of the home and community care (HACC) scheme in Tasmania? Is it true, as claimed, that the HACC scheme is dogged by administrative wrangling and government buck-passing? Is the Minister aware that from the Tasmanian Budget Papers it appears that the Tasmanian Government is not making a sufficient contribution to gain the full HACC entitlement from the Commonwealth? Is it true that for the 1987-88 financial year, due to the Tasmanian Government's reluctance to fulfil its commitments of providing $1 for every $2 of Commonwealth expenditure, HACC in Tasmania will miss out on $721,000? Is this on top of the half a million dollars forgone last year by the Tasmanian Government? Similarly, is it true that the supported accommodation assistance program (SAAP) will also suffer to the tune of $331,000 because of this same reluctance by the Tasmanian Government to contribute adequately to that scheme? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND ELECTORAL ROLL RECORDS: SECURITY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. In answering my question of 23 September the Minister advised the Senate that it was a fact that Department of Social Security microfiche master files were found scattered around a Melbourne suburb. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether electoral roll microfiche were also found with these Social Security master file microfiche? If electoral roll microfiche were found, could the Minister please explain the arrangements which prevail for the acquisition of electoral roll microfiche by the Department of Social Security? Can he also indicate whether the security of the current method for destruction is equivalent to that used by Australian Electoral Commission officers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some Department of Social Security microfiche records were apparently found in a Melbourne street in April this year, as I informed Senator Patterson some time ago. The records apparently included microfiche records provided to Social Security by the Australian Electoral Commission. Senator Patterson did direct a question to me on this some time ago, and this response is somewhat similar.

ANSWER.PARA: The present regime for microfiche security was laid down in correspondence between the then Australian Electoral Office and the Director-General of the Department of Social Security, commencing with an agreement relating to magnetic tapes. Further discussions concerned microfiche, and similar procedures were agreed to in February 1983. The essence of the security arrangements is that Social Security would arrange for the collection of superseded micro- fiche, accumulate them in secured storage areas and eventually burn them in industrial incinerators. After this process, a certificate indicating the number of sets destroyed each month would be supplied to the Electoral Commission. Later in February 1983, Social Security varied the guidelines to replace Australia Post by approved contract services. This variation was accepted by the Electoral Office in March 1983. This agreement is still in force, and confirmation of it was received in a telex from Social Security as recently as 3 July 1987.

As outlined in my answer before, an inquiry into the loss of the records found that it occurred due to an error on the part of the contractor responsible for their destruction. Some microfiche collected by the firm became mixed with non-security waste and were lost in transit for disposal. New arrangements with the firm have been made to ensure that such an incident does not recur. The contractor has undertaken to store the material in the firm's security vault, prior to sending it by sealed container for supervised destruction. Social Security is also investigating options for alternative collection and destruction methods.

The other departments and authorities supplied with sets of electoral roll microfiche are the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; the Australian Federal Police; the Department of Resources; Supreme Court offices; the Australian Taxation Office; the Attorney-General's Department; the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office; the National Crime Authority; the Department of Administrative Services; and the Department of Transport and Communications. Similar security arrangements have been agreed on with each.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister seen a letter to the editor in today's Australian Financial Review which is critical of Government policies for manufacturing? I ask the Minister whether he accepts this claim of Mr Garry White, Policy Director of the New South Wales Farmers Association:

QUESTION.PARA: Government actions have done little to reduce protection and most policy decisions have worsened rather than improved the costs of protection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter has been drawn to my attention. It is part of the perennial debate which now goes on between representatives of farm organisations and of the manufacturing sector, or other sectors of the economy upon whom protective regimes impose costs-the farm sector or the resource sector. That debate was muted for some two decades in Australian history by the activities of the then Country Party, which sought to encourage manufacturing in this country by highly protective regimes. Mr White's comments are partly legitimate and partly not in the sense that the Government, since it was elected to office, has set about a program of gradually reducing tariffs in a number of industries. I certainly agree that a lowering of tariffs and other forms of import protection is desirable and essential.

ANSWER.PARA: Average rates of protection have fallen. The last available figures, I think, from the Industries Assistance Commission were for 1984-85, but departmental figures show a significant lowering of protection in heavily protected sectors of industry. In other sectors, programs are in place which will reduce protection significantly over the next few years. These reductions in protection from import competition have been designed not to cause upheaval in manufacturing but to assist the restructuring process essential to lifting Australia's competitiveness in world markets.

I notice that Mr White in his letter also criticises certain measures which the Government has put in place to stimulate research and development, innovation and so on in parts of the manufacturing and services economy. They are measures of general application but they are particularly applicable to those sectors of the economy. I certainly do not agree with Mr White's view that these incentives simply raise costs for other sectors. I regard that as a vast oversimplification of the situation. They have succeeded in triggering substantial research and development activity. That is very important in terms of raising industry world competitiveness.

I make the point, however, in passing that today at Question Time questions have been asked about statutory authorities which provide support mechanisms in the agricultural sectors. A range of measures is in place which provide highly protective and long-standing assistance to sectors of rural industry. I am not condemning that, except to say that I suspect they are rather geriatric organisations, and probably need close examination in terms of improving their efficiency and marketing performance.

Very high levels of research and development funds have been made available by governments of all political persuasion to research into rural industries. That has been so over a very long period. It has sometimes been claimed that the activities of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which were largely directed towards providing a research infrastructure for Australian rural industries, were perhaps one of the few things that stopped Australia going down what is sometimes called the Argentinean route in the 1950s and 1960s.

Research and development incentives paid by taxpayers' funds and so on are a burden on the community generally, as any expenditure by government is. The question is its appropriateness in terms of industry development and medium to long term benefits to this country. As I have said, I have seen Mr White's letter. The debate about these issues is alive and well, although not particularly well here in the Senate.
