SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Resolution of the Senate of 23 September 1987, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] to the Senate on or before the next day of sitting, without further considering the Bill or the matters referred to the Committee in relation to the Bill.
(2) That, upon receipt of the report of the Committee, the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] be laid aside, without any further question being put.

It will be obvious to honourable senators why this motion is being moved. The Opposition has made it clear that it would not allow the successful completion of this legislation, that it would use its powers of disallowance to disallow the regulations which would bring the Bill into effect. The Government, therefore, has no alternative but to recognise that the Bill cannot be proceeded with. We regret this for reasons that I will not repeat to the Senate now, as I had the opportunity to point out to the Senate, during debate on a matter of urgency moved by Senator Puplick yesterday, why the Government had sought to pursue this legislative reform and why we regret that we cannot proceed with it. It would be futile and a waste of the Senate's time to go over that ground again. However, I note that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) has several times called for the withdrawal of the Bill; so I expect the co-operation of the Opposition in this matter.

Senator Puplick, on behalf of the Opposition, has given notice of a very lengthy contingent motion which seeks to add an amendment to my motion which would virtually send the terms of reference requiring a full examination of the soon to be defunct Australia Card legislation and many matters associated with it back to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I put to the Senate that this is not a sensible course of action and I hope that the Senate will not agree with it. It is a case of Senator Puplick wanting to beat a dead horse. I hope that he has reconsidered the strategy which he was wedded to when he announced his amendment.

Quite clearly, the Senate has within its powers the capacity to examine, by way of a special committee, a standing committee or a select committee, any legislative measure that the Government brings before the Senate. The Government has already announced that we will be pursuing a package of measures alternative to the Australia Card legislation. We will not be reintroducing the Australia Card legislation by another name. We will not be seeking to establish a measure which will be the Australia Card by another name. We recognise that the obstructionist attitude of the Opposition will prevent that. We are not about to waste the time and resources of the Senate, of the Government or of the Australian people by pursuing a course of action which we know will be futile.

We have announced that we will pursue a package of alternative measures, all of which have been endorsed by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats at various stages. The parts of those alternative measures that require legislation will come before the Senate and will be able to be considered by the Senate according to the normal powers of the Senate. In that context, and accepting the reality of the Senate's powers to examine any legislation that comes before us, it is futile and very wasteful of Senator Puplick to wish the resources of the Senate Standing Committee to be tied up examining legislation which has no life and which will not come before the Senate again.

The Government has not worked out the detail of the alternative package of measures it will be bringing before us. Some measures, such as the privacy Bills and the Data Protection Agency measure, are already in a form which is close to their final form. They may require some slight amendment but the other parts of the Government's package-the implementation of the fraud report, the development of a nationally co-ordinated births, deaths and marriages register in co-operation with the States-are still to be worked out in detail. So there is no point at this stage in the Senate seeking a detailed examination of those measures.

When the Government, after widespread consultation, has developed a detailed package, then, of course, we would expect that the Senate would use its powers of examination through its various committee structures to examine them. But at this stage persons on the other side of the chamber, the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, and various Opposition senators have called for the withdrawal of the Bill. I am now taking the commonsense and practical steps necessary to get the Bill off the agenda and I hope that I will have the co-operation of the Senate in that. I also express again something I have expressed several times in the course of this very important debate on how the Government can bring in effective measures to deal with tax evasion and social welfare fraud: now that the tumult and the shouting have died down we might have constructive bipartisan consideration of an important problem facing the Australian people, and that is the massive tax evasion and fraud which still exist despite the improved measures the Government has been able to put into place. I commend the motion to the Senate and indicate that we will not accept Senator Puplick's amendment should he persist with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as you and as Senator Ryan would undoubtedly know, today is the feast of St Pelegia the Penitent. It is good to see Senator Ryan come into the chamber today as a penitent on the Australia Card. As she rightly said, the Australia Card Bill is soon to be defunct. We are glad to see the end of this ghastly piece of legislation which I remind you, Mr President, was introduced despite the recommendations of a parliamentary inquiry which Senator Aulich was at great pains yesterday to praise as a good and worthy exercise. Despite the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, the Government proceeded down a track which was always doomed to failure because in essence the people of Australia did not want the Australia Card. Through the efforts of individuals, such as Mr Ewart Smith, through the efforts of those thousands of Australians who signed petitions, wrote letters and made representations against the Australia Card and, may I say, through the efforts of members of the Liberal and National parties who early in the piece set their face against this Australia Card despite what was then perceived to be the bulk of public opinion-but because they were of the belief that the Australia Card legislation should not be introduced, that the Australia Card scheme should not be introduced, they fulfilled their democratic and proper role in spearheading the opposition to this legislation-we have now come to the point where the legislation is admitted by the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) to be at the stage of being, to use her words, soon to be defunct. We are glad of that. We believe this is a triumph both for the parliamentary process of inquiry and scrutiny and for the democratic process of making it clear that the will of the people was against the introduction of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan went on to say that we should not persist with seeking to have a continuing inquiry into issues raised by the Australia Card. The Opposition rejects that view. In line with Senator Ryan's request made just a few moments ago with which we are delighted to comply, that there ought to be a constructive and bipartisan examination of the issues, we will now give her a constructive and bipartisan examination of the issues by referring the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in order to do precisely that-to examine the issues in a constructive, bipartisan fashion and hopefully to assist her and the Government in bringing forward legislation dealing with such matters as privacy which will have the support of all sides of this chamber. I therefore move as an amendment to Senator Ryan's motion:
At end of motion, add:
``(3) That, while, in recognition of:
(a) the overwhelming public opposition to the proposed national identity card system; and
(b) the determination of the Senate to exercise its proper constitutional rights to disallow the regulations necessary to give effect to the national identification system proposed,

the Government is not now pursuing the Australia Card Bill 1986, it has nevertheless not given any guarantees not to introduce the legislation in an amended form nor to establish a national identification system by some other means, and the concerns of the Senate regarding the effectiveness, cost and imposition upon personal privacy still remain, the following matters therefore be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for report on or before 1 May 1988:
(a) the provisions of the Australia Card Bill 1986 considered in the light of the reports of the Joint Select Committee on the Australia Card and of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee;

(b) the feasibility of any proposed national identity system operating in the event of a failure of any one or more States to co-operate on the establishment of a births, deaths and marriages register;
(c) the extent to which new or updated computer systems and recent crackdown campaigns on welfare cheating and tax avoidance and evasion have obviated the need for a national identity system;

(d) the appropriate responses which should be made to the recommendations contained in the various Australian Federal Police reports on fraud against the Commonwealth and the Report of the Review of Systems for Dealing with Fraud of the Commonwealth;
(e) the direct cost to the private sector in establishing and maintaining any such system;

(f) the capacity of the proposed Data Protection Agency to adequately safeguard and protect the privacy of the individual and to control un- authorised use of any proposed national identity card and/or individual identification numbers by commercial organisations such as credit insurance companies and unincorporated associations and clubs;
(g) the desirability, timing and nature of comprehensive privacy legislation in Australia in the light of concerns raised in the debate over the proposed Australia Card legislation;
(h) the extent to which any proposed system should accord with OECD guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data (1981);

(i) the extent of personal data held on Australian citizens by Government Departments and Agencies and by private sector agencies, its level of accuracy, access to it and its cross-referencing within the Government sector;
(j) the security of data already held by Government Departments and Agencies;
(k) the physical security of dedicated land lines and other data transmission facilities currently in use or proposed;
(l) the appropriate range and level of penalties on individuals and other entities, which should be imposed for the improper use or release of personal data;
(m) the evidence available from overseas as to the experience of other countries with identity card systems; including the taking of evidence from overseas expert witnesses;
(n) the usefulness of any card and numbering system in achieving the objectives of reducing the extent of the cash economy, organised crime and large-scale tax evasion and welfare fraud; and
(o) any matters relevant to the preceding.''

The terms of reference are somewhat different from those which were originally given to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee in order simply to reflect the actual absence of the Australia Card Bill from being currently in the possession of the Senate, which will be the case when the motion, as amended, is agreed to and the Bill has been formally withdrawn. Nevertheless, there are a couple of matters to which I will make brief reference in dealing with the terms of reference. In order to demonstrate the value which I believe a continuing inquiry by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee will have for the Parliament and for the united efforts on both sides of the chamber to come to grips with the problems of privacy legislation, the adequacy of the Data Protection Agency as proposed, the costs to the private sector, the value of the upgraded computer system, the recent crackdown campaign on welfare cheating and tax avoidance, the comments made by the Federal police and the review of the system dealing with fraud of the Commonwealth, I point out that it will for the first time also permit a parliamentary inquiry to take a wider look at the extent of personal data held on Australian citizens by government departments and agencies.
I want to turn briefly to a couple of matters within the proposed terms of reference. Firstly, I take the question of privacy. Sub-paragraph (f), which will become term of reference (f), refers to:
the capacity of the proposed Data Protection Agency to adequately safeguard and protect the privacy of the individual . . .

We believe that if the Government is serious about proceeding with having a Data Protection Agency, here is the opportunity to look at what was proposed in the Australia Card Bill and to make suggestions to the Government about how that Data Protection Agency should operate, how it should be established, what its powers should be and what its effectiveness should be in achieving the shared aims of protection of individual privacy and preventing the unauthorised use of data. Similarly, the Committee will note the desirability, timing and nature of comprehensive privacy legislation. We all accept that this is long overdue. Professor Morrison's report goes back to, I think, 1973. The report of the Law Reform Commission goes back to, I think, 1983. Here is an opportunity to look at questions of privacy legislation. The terms of reference go on to suggest the extent to which any proposed system should accord with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development guidelines on the protection of privacy and transborder flows of personal data established in 1981. Then we add a term of reference which I think is most important. It reads as follows:

the extent of personal data held on Australian citizens by Government Departments and Agencies and by private sector agencies, its level of accuracy, access to it and its cross-referencing within the Government sector;

This will be a first opportunity for a parliamentary inquiry to examine how much data is held on Australian citizens by the Government, by its departments and its agencies and, in response to legitimate points which have been raised on every possible occasion, how much information on individuals is held by the private sector agencies. It will test the accuracy of data held by government, which is a most important aspect to look at. It will examine who has access to that information and how much it is cross-referenced within the government sector. I was interested at Question Time today-and I see Senator Robert Ray is in the chamber-to hear the answers given by Senator Richardson about the exchange of data between the Australian Electoral Commission and the Department of Social Security. In fact, that was adverted to in the Joint Select Committee report in terms of a program matching exercise which took place between the Electoral Commission, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Immigration. But people do not know-it is not on the public record-precisely what arrangements exist within government for the exchange of that data.

That may be perfectly proper and perfectly legitimate, but it needs to be put on the public record so that the Parliament can decide whether the internal arrangements made between the Electoral Commission and the Department of Social Security, or the Electoral Commission and the Department of Immigration, or the Department of Immigration and the Department of Defence, or whatever it happens to be, are proper and legitimate uses of that data, bearing in mind that the same people may well appear as having quite different characteristics on different records held by different departments. For instance, it is certainly possible that for taxation purposes a person may be seen to have dependent children or not to have dependent children, depending on their age, which may not be the same record as is maintained by the Department of Social Security or the Department of Employment, Education and Training, as the authorities making payments for these dependent children. Therefore, the same person may well appear in some departmental records as having dependants and in other departmental records as not having dependants. It is important to know that if there is cross linkage of these, there is some method by which the accuracy of the data can be verified and it does not act as a detriment to the rights of the individual concerned.

We are also suggesting that the Committee should have a look at the question of the security of data and the physical security both of the holding of data and of the transmission of data. Honourable senators will recall that, in a series of questions asked in this place and in the House of Representatives of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, and of his junior Minister, the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, Mr Duncan, some quite different opinions were revealed about the security of dedicated landlines over which data is transmitted around the country. An admission was made, both by Mr Duncan and by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that it is possible, in certain circumstances, for people to have physical access to this data. Here is an opportunity for the Committee to have a look at that question to see whether steps can be taken to improve the adequacy of the security of data when it is being transmitted in that fashion.

We asked for the Committee to look at the range and level of penalties on individuals and other entities which should be imposed for the improper use or release of personal data. The penalties that are currently in place, which ought to have been used against those officers in the Health Insurance Commission who were involved in quite scandalous attempts to release information for party political purposes-as revealed in the leakage of information about doctors' incomes and, subsequently, the release of information relevant to the McGoldrick case-were not a sufficient deterrent to make people think twice about undertaking those sorts of activities. The Committee will be able to look at that. The Committee will be able to look at the available information and experience from overseas in exactly the same way as the first Joint Select Committee was asked to listen to the views of Mr Lars Tegnhed, the Director of the National Swedish Tax Board.

Finally, the Committee is empowered to look at the usefulness of any card and numbering system in achieving the objectives of reducing the extent of the cash economy, organised crime and large scale tax evasion and welfare fraud. I do not believe that anybody could possibly object to those terms of reference as far as that is concerned. We have had a whole series of debates over questions of organised crime. I noted, for instance, a very interesting article which appeared in the September 1987 issue of Newsweek headed `A Thriving Trade in Fake ID's'. That is a very lengthy article on the extent to which quite sophisticated identity cards are subject to organised forgery in the university system in the United States of America which indicates the massive degree of sophistication which is possible to be brought to this question-and, after all, these are only student identity cards which are being forged in this case.

A whole series of issues can be looked at in terms of the way in which any numbering or identification system will reduce the extent of organised crime rather than simply provide yet another avenue for the expansion of organised criminal activities. It will allow a proper examination of the question of the cash economy-something which the Joint Select Committee had a preliminary examination of but did not have the opportunity to study in great detail. Nobody on the Government side of the Senate has effectively answered the question of how any form of national identification system will have a significant impact upon the operation of the cash economy.

The Committee will also look at questions of cost. One of the other great advantages of having this Committee inquiry will be to put an end to a large number of the lies and misrepresentations being told about the Australia Card, including the degree to which it would have any financial benefit to the Commonwealth. All sorts of claims have been made. The Prime Minister has claimed that it will save $1 billion. Senator Ryan has claimed that it will save $900m. Claims were made before the Joint Select Committee that it would save about $750m. Yet, as Senator Haines very rightly pointed out yesterday, all these things are subject to revision on the basis of the fact that there have been major changes made since those estimates were made and there has certainly been a large amount of double counting as far as those things are concerned. An editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 18 September this year states in part:

The Government has not presented a skerrick of evidence to support its claim of a $1 billion improvement in tax revenue. In fact, it can hardly be denied that the round figure of $1 billion stands in its own right as a denial of the Government's claims-it is an estimate, plucked out of the air by some shadowy bureaucrat.

This will simply allow the Committee to look at those issues now that we have additional evidence which relates both to the new taxation scales and to the new data which we have about the benefit or otherwise of the prescribed payments system. It will have a look at the extent to which the Government's internal rearrangements of the Australian Taxation Office and its more effective policing of the welfare system have allowed a number of the problems which were advanced before the Joint Select Committee to be adequately dealt with already.

Therefore, the Opposition will persist by moving this amendment to the Minister's motion. It believes that ongoing and continuing inquiry by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee will provide the basis for sound legislation to be brought forward, particularly in areas such as privacy, and that it will take on board a lot of work which the Government admits was likely to occur when it brought in privacy legislation, which might well have then been referred to a Senate Select Committee or, if it had proceeded with its cash transactions legislation, which might well have been referred to a Senate Select Committee. In line with the Minister's claim, which we accept in good faith-that there ought to be constructive and bipartisan consideration of the issues involved-we will provide that constructive, bipartisan consideration of the issues by persisting with our amendment to the Minister's motion and having this matter referred to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee for report by 1 May 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating a motion that was put down by the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, in the following terms, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] . . .
This reference was made by this chamber to that Committee some two weeks ago and that Committee was to report today. The motion continues:
That, upon receipt of the report of the Committee the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3] be laid aside, without any further question being put.

That would end the investigation and discussion, not only on the national identification card system that the Government originally proposed, but also on any alternative system. Indeed, it would prevent a committee inquiring into the effectiveness of other measures that this Government has introduced, in particular in the last 10 months but in general over the last four years, to crack down on tax and social security fraud. I was a little disturbed to hear the Minister say that she thought we ought to abandon all references of this kind because it is a waste of time sending these things to a committee and having a report brought down when, as she said, the Government has no intention of coming up with a national identification card system under another name. That is all very well and good and every senator on this side of the chamber at least is very pleased to hear that. However, the amendment which was moved by Senator Puplick and which we will support in fact covers a number of areas that I think require looking into in general. In particular, I refer to item (c) of paragraph (b), which states:
the extent to which new or updated computer systems and recent crackdown campaigns on welfare cheating and tax avoidance and evasion have obviated the need for a national identity system.

In the speech that I made on this matter yesterday I pointed out that over the last year or so the Government has instituted a number of extensive procedures to crack down on social welfare fraud and tax cheating-measures which, on the most conservative estimates available from departments, ministerial Press releases, Budget Papers and so on, have netted this Government in the vicinity of $823m annually in excess of that netted in previous years. As I said yesterday, most of us acknowledged that it is impossible to get blood out of the same stone twice. I am disturbed too that Senator Ryan seems to think that it is a waste of the time of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to look at what may happen in regard to the feasibility of any proposed identity system operating in the event of a failure of any one or more States to co-operate in the establishment of a births, deaths and marriages register. I think it is mutually exclusive to be that and also to hold two, three or more tax file numbers. However, we need to know whether there will be any impediment to improving the integrity of that tax file number if State governments refuse to co-operate as far as births, deaths and marriages registers are concerned. Unlike Senator Ryan, I do not think it is a waste of time to find out the capacity of the proposed Data Protection Agency adequately to safeguard and protect the privacy of the individual and to control unauthorised use of any proposed system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until you see the legislation, then.

—It is no good the Minister bleating at me that I ought to wait until I see the legislation. We need to know the capacity and effectiveness of any data protection agency and, indeed, of any privacy legislation. The Government knows as well as do senators on this side of the chamber that constitutionally there are some impediments to introducing effective privacy legislation that will protect ordinary citizens from data abuse by the private sector. Therefore, it is a valid requirement of this chamber that we know the basis on which we are working. If the foundations are going to crumble even before we get started, those foundations need to be fixed before we build anything more on them. That is what lies behind the amendment moved by Senator Puplick to the Minister's motion.

SPEECH.PARA: We also need to look at the physical security of dedicated landlines and other data transmission facilities. Most of us know that a dedicated landline is certainly more secure than an ordinary telephone line. Nobody is going to argue about that. Nevertheless, before we start on something that may depend on the security of dedicated landlines we need to know just what integrity that physical security has. We need to know also the appropriate range and level of penalties that need to be imposed on individuals and entities following the improper use or release of personal data. I think that one of the problems with the old Bill was that far smaller penalties were proposed to be imposed on individuals within departments who leaked information-assuming such individuals could be found-than was proposed to be imposed on ordinary citizens such as employers and individuals who did not use the card when it was supposed to be used. Therefore, for the Minister to argue that it is a waste of time to prepare the groundwork before the Government goes off on another frolic is, I think, rather absurd. I am pleased also to note that Senator Puplick has himself learned a lesson from the last reference we moved to have this matter looked at by a committee. With respect, his reporting date of 1 May is a much more sensible one. Indeed, with the greatest respect to Senator Puplick, it is a much better reporting date.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know what that paragraph means, Senator.

—Indeed we do. In the language of this place, with the greatest respect, I think that Senator Puplick's reporting date of on or before 1 May 1988 is a far more reasonable one than the date he proposed earlier this year, having objected to our later reporting date. On balance, I think it is important that we get the foundations of any proposed system laid down and made secure. I think it is important that the Australian public and we in this place have information on which to base our support or opposition. I have acknowledged before that a lot of the opposition to the Australia Card was couched in highly emotive, somewhat irrational and fearmongering terms. I do not subscribe to that. As far as I am concerned there was enough in the Bill on which to mount an opposition without rampaging through the fear, confusion and incitement to riot that some people did.
—Fanned by your mob.

—So the importance of this reference is to get some facts into the argument-facts which have been missing from Senator Schacht's side of the chamber. I ask Senator Schacht not to enter this argument because he is responsible for what I believe is a $1m debt in the Australian Labor Party in South Australia. I ask him not to talk to me about how to organise finances; Senator Schacht would not know how to organise his finances. Maybe if Senator Schacht had had an inquiry into the system over there--
—Order! I ask Senator Haines to address her remarks through the Chair.

—Certainly, Mr Deputy President. I point out that for Senator Schacht to be carrying on as he is runs counter to the fact that he cannot even get the finances of the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party in order. Therefore, I think that he does not need to be listened to. On balance, I think it is unarguable that the terms of reference included in Senator Puplick's amendment need to be addressed by the Parliament. We will be supporting that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing I regret when there is a major political fracas is the rather inadequate analysis that follows because myths perpetuate, and there is the brilliance of hindsight-all sorts of things come forward. I think I heard Senator Puplick say today that the majority of Australians oppose the Australia Card. I am not sure that that statement is true. I do not think there is enough empirical evidence to justify that claim. I concede that at the moment the percentage is about 50-50 because, as the honourable senator would know, many of the polls that we go by have been quick ones, for example, by telephone and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I put this on the record about the Australia Card: We went through due process and we cannot be criticised for that. First of all we introduced legislation which was based on the views that we had expressed at the national Taxation Summit. That legislation was defeated in this chamber. We then brought it back to this chamber, having allowed a proper amount of time to go by. A joint parliamentary inquiry looked into the matter and it brought forward all sorts of conflicting evidence. We then had a double dissolution on this issue, as is required by the Constitution when there is a conflict between the two Houses. We then reintroduced the legislation into the House of Representatives where it was passed and we brought it back to the Senate.

The reason that we are debating Senator Ryan's motion today is that we would have thought, normally and historically, that the due process was for a joint sitting and that that would resolve the matter. What some people have described as a technical deficiency in the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]-that it needed regulations to support it and that they would be knocked back by one chamber of the Parliament-in my view abrogates those provisions in the Constitution that the founding fathers meant to apply. I do not get excited about that matter. We talk about constitutional vandalism too much but definitely, on balance, I feel more comfortable morally and on the basis of principle than those opposite should when it comes to that point. Indeed, even the hero of the hour, Mr Ewart Smith, concedes that the Bill had no technical defects, that in fact that is the way Bills should be constructed in a democracy and that we should do things not by proclamation but by regulation.

In any event, we did not initially introduce the Australia Card Bill as a double dissolution measure. Of course, a government is fairly much bound to present the same Bill the second time after a double dissolution, so the Australia Card Bill could not be altered. When it was introduced into this chamber some of us optimistically hoped that it would go through. I think there were some worried views on the other side of the chamber because there was talk of two or three senators crossing the floor to prevent a possible trigger for a double dissolution. It is interesting to note that two of the three senators are no longer members of this place. The Liberal Party of Australia dropped them off. Senator Jessop and Senator Townley have been disposed of. We on this side of the chamber-I go into the byways for just a moment, Mr Deputy President-are subject to discipline and we admit it. Those opposite are free spirits; they are free to go when they do not toe the party line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what happened to Senator Georges.

—Senator Georges resigned from the Party; he was not expelled. He would have been. The base line on the Australia Card debate is not so much a civil libertarian matter. The reason that the Liberal Party so courageously opposed it and the majority of Australians were in favour of it had nothing to do with civil liberties. It was basically a strategy to prevent and to deny the Government as much revenue as possible. The underlying theory of that is that the Government is denied revenue, the heat in the pressure cooker is turned up and therefore the Government has to apply other taxes or unpopular expenditure cuts. That is the name of the game; that is the 4 1/2-year strategy so far of the Liberal Party.
—It has not been one of its most successful.

—It has not been one of its most successful ones, as Senator Ryan points out. But that basically is it. Nothing stops the Liberal Party or changes the Liberal Party's strategy. That is the basis of it: to deprive this Government of revenue and therefore force it into new revenue areas or unpopular expenditure cuts. That was the original basis of Liberal Party opposition to the Australia Card. It would be untrue to say that the argument was then just dressed up in civil libertarian arguments because enough people on the other side believed in the civil libertarian arguments to give that basic strategy credibility. I do not imply that all Liberals who opposed the Australia Card did so from base motive but the actual motive behind it for the mainstream Liberal Party is as I have stated.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party wants to persist with having an inquiry. Within a couple of days we have seen the Liberal Party go from unctuous principle to rather grubby opportunism. Let us look at this tax file issue. I ask myself why the Liberals and the National Party of Australia-I will come to the Australian Democrats at a later point-supported the upgrading and extensive use of a tax file number in the first inquiry. Did they believe in it or did they, lacking in courage, realising that a majority of Australians supported the Australia Card, just support the tax file number as a tactic, knowing that we would not support it because we had some doubts that it was not of the highest integrity? Did they support it just as a tactic to ameliorate criticism of themselves for opposing the Australia Card? The answer has come through very clearly in the last few days and it is yes. Their support of the tax file number was bogus; it was a mere political tactic.

The Australia Card Bill is now finished. We have admitted it. Senator Ryan has moved a motion to withdraw it. Will the Liberal Party support a tax file number system? Probably not. It comes back to the central strategy. Massive civil libertarian arguments are not really involved here. There is already a tax file number. Its integrity is questionable because of the lack of a national births and deaths registry but that is a completely different argument. Again the Liberal Party starts backing off. Mr Wilson Tuckey has more than backed off; he has bolted. He can hardly be restrained by the rest of the Liberal Party. This matter comes back to the Liberal Party's central strategy. It will not support an upgraded tax file number because it will bring in more revenue to this Government. Alternatively, the Liberal Party will seek to delay the implementation of an upgraded tax file number so that no fresh revenue will come in before the next election. In turn, it wants to force us into a situation of imposing new revenue measures or unpopular expenditure cuts.

In many ways a further inquiry would get the Liberal Party off the hook for a long while. Whilst we on this side of the chamber maintain that we want an upgraded tax file number, what will be the Liberal response throughout October, November and December through to 1 May? I will be very surprised if the report is in by 1 May. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will come back to the Parliament asking for an extension of time and if we do not grant it we are claimed to be undemocratic. The report will probably be presented in June, July or August next year. The Liberal Party does not have to say one thing on what it would do. It would say, `Let the Senate inquiry decide. This marvellous, impartial body with the wisdom of Solomon will go away and make a decision on this aspect'. Therefore, once again, the Liberal Party does not have to come up with any alternative policies.

Over the last three years time and time again we have asked the Liberal Party, `What is your tax policy?'. It has been so critical of the fringe benefits tax, the lump sum tax on superannuation and of putting an assets test on pensions. In those three years the Liberal Party was negative. Time and time again we asked it what its alternative was. And what happened? An election was announced and it had to scramble together an alternative that made major mathematical blunders, that had at least $2.6 billion in unspecified expenditure cuts. The whole thing was a farce. Once again the Liberal Party is asking for another seven or eight months grace in which to say what it would do on tax policy and therefore we should have an inquiry.

Senate inquiries do not have the wisdom of Solomon; they are not impartial; they are partisan committees, occasionally interrupted by a co-operative approach and objectivity. They will reflect the prejudices and the bias already existing in this debate. It cannot be argued that just by sending the matter to a Senate committee we will get absolute objectivity. Of course we will not. I hope that coalition members-I am not including Senator Puplick-actually attend the hearings this time, and are not like Mr Blunt, who occasionally drops in to committee hearings, be they of the Australia Card Committee or of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. We can always formulate great views! I think that he must be a man of great intellect, not to hear the evidence but to be able to agree with so many resolutions at the end. I hope that does not happen on this occasion. I hope that the people who force this motion through attend all the committee hearings and are very diligent about the matter.

A couple of other points have been made in this debate. Senator Puplick mentioned the Australian Electoral Commission. He said that that matter is not on the public record. I hasten to disagree with him. Knowledge of the Electoral Commission records being given to government departments has had wide publicity. It was subject to fairly intense scrutiny by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. That was one of the reasons why the suggestion came out that maybe all electoral records should be more publicly available, rather than to specific departments. Also, all those records are subject to freedom of information searches. I think that the matter introduced by Senator Puplick was a red herring.

I just want to go to one or two other points. One of the main justifications for holding a further committee inquiry was the allegation made by Senator Puplick and Senator Haines that our estimates of revenue gains from the Australia Card probably are wildly out. They might be right; I doubt it. But I have heard such accusations made before. We were told that the fringe benefits tax would not bring in anywhere near the revenue that we claimed. We always said our claims were conservative and we put in a bottom line figure. We have been proved right. It was claimed that our approach to substantiation was wrong; that we would be hundreds of millions of dollars out; and that it would not bring in that amount of revenue. We said we were conservative. We were; it brought in more money.

We said the same thing about the capital gains tax. It brought in more money. We said the same thing about tax on lump sum superannuation. Again, it brought in the money we claimed it would, or a little more. Finally, when we made the claim in 1983 that we would create 500,000 jobs within one year, the cynical laughter wafted over from the Liberal Party. Again, we were proved correct.

We have not had a bad track record on some of these predictions. No government is perfect but we have never been as far out as Senator Puplick and Senator Haines would have us believe we are on the Australia Card. We have been immensely closer to our Budget targets than was the Liberal Government in its preceding seven years. Generally, again we have been on the conservative side. If we have said the deficit would be $2 billion it has generally been under what we have predicted. So I do not really place much emphasis on the honourable senators' allegation.

Let me just come to the last point. I listened to Senator Haines's plaintive plea for this matter to go to a committee. She is like someone who has been given a birthday party and wants it to last six months. She had one of her very few victories in politics and it is all too fragmentary and elusive; it is about to slip away. So she wants to have a big party for another six months to enjoy that success. I can understand that. It is very hard, when one does not have much success in politics, to let that one ephemeral moment disappear into the distance.

But I believe the support by the Democrats for sending this matter to a committee is totally opportunistic. I really do. I listened three weeks ago to a couple of Democrat senators extolling in this chamber the virtues of the tax file number and saying how wrong we were to persist with the Australia Card. Now we have been defeated and thwarted in that legislation we ask the Democrats for their support for the tax file number. Where are they? They are disappearing off into the sunset like a pack of Bedouins disappearing into the desert, never to be found again.

I am very indebted to Senator Cooney for an anecdote he told me the other day. It sums up the Democrats' attitude on this matter. In the middle of the Federal election at the Customs House in Melbourne-this is a large government building where members are housed-a window cleaner was washing windows high up on the building. Unfortunately, the mechanical device he was standing on collapsed and he was hanging on to his life by a thread. The emergency services were rung. All the television cameras came. What was the Democrats' contribution? Two of them ran out with a big sign saying `Vote Democrat'. That sort of opportunism has again been reflected here today. My two Democrat senatorial colleagues who are in the chamber do not come from Victoria and cannot be blamed for that, but that is the sort of opportunism they have been indulging in here today.

The Democrats should do what is the hardest thing in politics: having won on this issue, they should win with grace. Over the next several months they will be coming up with a range of propositions on what they believe we should do in the expenditure area. The Democrats are very good at that and always have been. The one creative thing about the Democrats is their views on spending money. I do not disagree with them all. Sometimes I disagree with the priority. The Democrats will be coming to us and saying, `You should be spending money in this or that area'. But the one thing about which they never come to us-they have not come to us over 4 1/2 years about it-is on how we raise that money. When we have put propositions in this chamber sometimes they have supported us-and we appreciate that-but at other times they have frustrated us in terms of revenue raising and in our efforts to combat tax evasion and tax avoidance.

On this matter, the Democrats have an opportunity to respond quickly. I cannot give a guarantee on how long it will take the Government to get its alternative package together. But if we have it together by the end of November, we will want to put it to this chamber and have it put in place. We do not want to have to wait for some nebulous inquiry to come back, maybe on 1 May, May Day, or, with an extension of time, the following August and be frustrated out of another year's revenue.

In conclusion, I remind the Democrats what the base line of all this is. We are not talking about some fancy Dan tax avoidance scheme; we are talking about blatant tax evasion that has persisted in this country for 20, 30 or 40 years, by which a large range of people are criminally evading taxation. We all agree that we must deal with it. Let us get on with it. We have had enough inquiries. We know what the issues are. I ask the Democrats to give us an opportunity to develop alternative legislation. Quite obviously, if that legislation is unsatisfactory, they will dud us and send it off to a committee. But I believe that they should have given us the opportunity to put forward an alternative package. It is only about two weeks since this issue was pronounced dead-and a week later the funeral was on. Now the Dem- ocrats should give us a chance to put forward an alternative package. As I said to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, the motives for sending this matter to committees are varied. They are basically opportunistic and political humbug. The Senate should reject Senator Puplick's amendment and support Senator Ryan's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate long on this issue but I have to say that if Australians wanted some very hard evidence that the factor governing the position of the coalition on fraud and tax cheats is nothing but common or garden politics, rather than any proper attempt to come to grips with the subject, this amendment provides that evidence. It is a classic piece of humbuggery from Senator Puplick. We need only refer to the details of the amendment that we are expected to agree with to see that. The opening shot, part (a), says:

SPEECH.PARA: the provisions of the Australia Card Bill 1986 considered in the light of the reports of the Joint Select Committee on the Australia Card and of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee;

This part of the proposed amendment shows that the Opposition wants a committee to re-examine the Australia Card. Senator Puplick, in his contribution to this debate today, said that one of the concerns this committee would be able to investigate was the question of cost. What a classic piece of humbuggery it is to put that forward and, at the same time, have it as the opening shot of the proposed amendment to re-examine the Australia Card.

The Government, the Senate and the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card conducted a very extensive pre-natal examination of that legislation. We are now having a debate where the corpse is being buried with full military honours. Senator Puplick wants to spend another fortune in public money to carry out an autopsy, a post mortem, on it. What a piece of absolute nonsense that is. We do not need it. We know why the legislation died. The cause of death is right in front of us. We do not need to spend any more money carrying out a post mortem. Yet that is what is proposed in part (a) of the amendment.

I go on to indicate just a few other parts of what we are supposed to be agreeing with. I must say that I am extremely disappointed that-and this has been said already by other speakers from this side of the House-the Australian Democrats are supporting this amendment because the purpose of the amendment has nothing whatever to do with the Australia Card, as Senator Robert Ray correctly pointed out. It has nothing whatever to do with examining any issues connected with the card. When one examines the amendment one finds out why. Under part (f) of the amendment we have to examine:
the capacity of the proposed Data Protection Agency to adequately safeguard and protect the privacy of the individual . . .
Later the amendment continues:
(l) the appropriate range and level of penalties on individuals and other entities, which should be imposed for the improper use or release of personal data;
(m) the evidence available from overseas as to the experience of other countries with identity card systems including the taking of evidence from overseas expert witnesses;
(n) the usefulness of any card and numbering system in achieving the objectives of reducing the extent of the cash economy, organised crime and large-scale tax evasion and welfare fraud;

I will not waste any more time of the Senate by reading any more sections from this amendment which we shall vote on in a few minutes. I just wish to point out to honourable senators that every single section of this amendment was canvassed exhaustively by the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, of which Senator Puplick was a member.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it was not.

—I challenge Senator Puplick on that interjection. I stand by what I have said. I have carefully read every page of the Hansard transcript of the evidence put to that Joint Select Committee, as well as the report. I might add that I also read the exhaustive addendum to the report attached by Senator Puplick himself. Every single section of this amendment that I have just read out was examined. I do not say that all the parts of every section of the amendment were examined. Of course not. How could they be when some of the parts of the amendment refer to the fact that the Australia Card is now dead? But those particular sections of the amendment that I have just read out to the Senate were all exhaustively canvassed before the Select Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick, who has great concern about the expenditure of public money, wants to do it all again. I would say from my experience during my short time in this chamber and from having read the entire proceedings before the Joint Select Committee, that all these matters have been talked to death. There is certainly no need to examine them again. But, as Senator Robert Ray so accurately pointed out and as 10 seconds examination by anyone would reveal, the reality is that this proposal and this amendment have nothing whatever to do with any genuine attempt to come to grips with fraud or tax evasion. This is a classic procedure to maintain the prominence of Senator Puplick and Senator Haines for another six or seven months and to tie up the Senate in a lot of completely unnecessary investigation. What the Opposition and the Democrats should do-and they have the numbers to do so-is wait until a specific proposal for combating fraud and tax evasion is put before the Parliament by the Government and then, if they wish, refer it to whatever committee they want for examination of the issues raised by that legislation. If the Opposition and the Democrats are serious about this they should wait until they see what the Government proposes instead of dealing with Senator Puplick's fantasies about what might need to be dealt with. As I said before, a great deal of this amendment has already been done to death by the Joint Select Committee of which Senator Puplick was a member. I have my own ideas as to why they do not follow that course.

Senator Haines raised the point during this morning's debate that she wants to examine the meaning of the words `upgraded tax file number'. She said, `Oh well, we cannot have a situation in which there is an extended tax file number. What is meant by an upgraded tax file number?'. Senator Haines must have been out to lunch on the day that that matter was examined in detail by the Joint Select Committee. A Mr McDermott of the Australian Taxation Office-and I have canvassed this issue in debates here already-spent four pages of Hansard transcript explaining precisely what was meant by an upgraded tax file number. There is no need for Senator Haines to support an amendment asking for a committee to examine it; it is already there. Why do we have to waste taxpayers' money in referring that issue again when it is already there in the transcript of proceedings of a joint select committee which has already held sittings? And it did not cost peanuts to run that particular exercise.

If honourable senators want to know what an upgraded tax file number is I refer them to page 3964 of the Hansard transcript of the Joint Select Committee and they will find out. A precise description of such a number is contained there-a description, I might add, with which Senator Puplick agreed enthusiastically. I shall quote from the transcript. When the question of security of the data collected by the Australian Taxation Office was raised, there was an exchange between the Taxation Office and Senator Puplick which is worthy of quoting. The transcript reads:

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Brown-

SPEECH.PARA: that is Mr Bob Brown-
is quite correct. If we all trusted every department as much as we trust the Tax Office, we would not have the problems that we have at the moment.

I do not disagree with those sentiments of Senator Puplick. In fact, considering the millions of files and the highly confidential information that is held by the Taxation Office, it has an impeccable record of safeguarding that information. So Senator Puplick's statement is perfectly justifi- able. As far as the upgraded tax file number is concerned, Senator Puplick does not have any concerns about the retention of information by the Taxation Office and its ability to safeguard that information. His sentiments are already expressed there. Page 3960 of the transcript says:

TALK.START.PARA: —Let met test you on that. If in fact one were to have all of the procedures which are proposed for the issue of the Australia Card but in fact only at the end of the day issue a `tax file number', your problem would be overcome--

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the problems of the Taxation Office. The transcript continues:
Mr McDermott-I still do not understand. What do we do with the taxpayer who is unable to prove his identity or unwilling to prove his identity for taxation file number purposes?

TALK.START.PARA: —You misunderstand what I am putting to you. What I am putting to you is that if we go through the whole of this procedure-

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the procedure for interviews and the issuing of a plastic card without a photograph, a common number and the whole bit because that is what he is referring to and that is what Mr McDermott spent four pages of Hansard describing-
but instead of issuing an Australia Card and an Australia Card number we simply issue a taxation file number, your problem is solved, is it not?
Mr McDermott-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely. Thank you.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the same section of the Hansard transcript that I referred to in the debate on the Australia Card Bill a week or so ago. That is an additional section and if honourable senators are interested enough to go back to this transcript they will find consistent evidence of Senator Puplick's support for the upgraded tax file number as, indeed, he very precisely laid out in the final three paragraphs of the report which he chose to add to the report of the Joint Select Committee. We do not need any investigation of what an upgraded tax file number means. Senator Puplick and other members of that Committee are precisely aware of that and, as I have said, they agreed to it.

Senator Haines, of course, is all over the place when it comes to the Australia Card. In her contribution to the debate that we had on this matter a couple of weeks ago she really intrigued me because in the space of five minutes she contradicted herself. She asked how the Australian Labor Party could claim that the Australia Card was an issue during the election campaign. She said that the issue was not raised by the Labor Party and that it was not an issue at all. Just five minutes later-and I am referring to the Hansard record on this-she said that the Australia Card was in fact the issue that got the Australian Democrats elected in the numbers that they are here in this chamber. I refer honourable senators to the Hansard transcript of that debate-thank God for Hansard! If one wants an indication of where Senator Haines is on this issue one can see that she does not know. It is an issue and it is not an issue.

Senator Stone, as a National Party senator for Queensland, has been regaling us about his concerns over civil rights, the right and proper role of the Senate in knocking back this legislation by using regulations and the great value of the Senate as a House of review and so on. Like a lot of other Labor senators, I look forward to the political reforms that are instituted in Queensland under the leadership of Senator Stone because obviously, on the basis of his argument, that must include the complete redrawing of the electoral boundaries of Queensland and the re-establishment of the Queensland Upper House with, of course, a non-government majority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.

—No, I would not, either. The saddest part of this debate-and I was interested to hear this from Senator Puplick, who spoke at length the other day-is that when Labor senators challenged Opposition senators to tell us what they would do, they would not do so. The Opposition has not done so-apart from an extraordinary contribution by the spokesperson for the Opposition, Wilson Tuckey, and I am glad the Opposition has got him and we have not. However, apart from that and apart from the totally unworkable proposal for working for the dole that has been thrown up by Senator Puplick again, I have yet to hear what the Opposition proposes instead. We have 16 million people in this country, spread over three and a half million square miles, in thousands of isolated and tiny communities, and the feasibility of instituting on a national basis the principle of working for the dole is a nonsense. It would be impossible to introduce or police. Perhaps it could be done in isolated major urban centres, but not Australia wide. In order to comply with the principles of fairness and equity, it would have to apply to everybody, not just to selected people. Therefore, I do not know how Opposition members intend to implement that proposal-and that is the only proposal that they have put forward so far.

SPEECH.PARA: When Opposition senators were asked by Labor senators what they intended to do, there was an interesting interjection from Senator Knowles, who called out, `That's your job-that's the Government's job'. Senator Puplick expanded on that and said `That is not our job. We are the Opposition. That's the job of the Government'. I am a newcomer to the Senate and to government. I do not know much about government, but I know a very great deal about opposition. I say as a dispassionate observer that in my view the Opposition in the Senate is pathetic. Over the last couple of weeks I have been interested to observe the abysmal performance of the Opposition at Question Time. It has failed to take opportunities which, were I on the Opposition benches, I would have grabbed very quickly. The Opposition in this place is not very good.

TALK.START.PARA: —No leadership.

—That is right, and that is the problem. Opposition members are nailed by the contributions of Senator Puplick and Senator Knowles to this debate. They have become a permanent opposition because they make comments as revealing and as asinine as, `We don't have any responsibility to put forward any constructive Opposition proposal-that is the Government's job'. That is what Senator Puplick said. Opposition members see their roles as expecting the Government to do the constructive things; the Government has to put up proposals and the sole responsibility of the Opposition is to knock them down.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members have the hide to talk about a preoccupation on the part of this Government with the abuse of power. The reality is that in this chamber it is the non-government senators who have the power, and in my view they have used it irresponsibly over the last couple of weeks. If Opposition members want to be nailed down firmly as a permanent opposition with an opposition mentality, they should continue to utter sentiments such as those offered in the Senate the other day. Senator Puplick has put his remarks on record and I am prepared to take him at his word, as I think he would want most Australians to take him at his word. PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many claims have been received by the Commonwealth for stress or other health disabilities caused to Bank employees and those of other financial institutions by bank robberies.

(2) How many of these claims have proved successful to the applicants, and what breakdown of mental and physical illness is available in respect of the Commonwealth Bank, Australian private banks, International banks, and other lending institutions who are known to handle ready money.
(3) How many claims were directly attributable to confrontations with bank robbers or would-be robbers carrying firearms in hold-up attempts.
(4) How many members of the general public during the same period have claimed for stress related medical conditions in similar circumstances, and how many have proved successful.
(5) In relation to (a) employees of financial institutions involved in gun-related bank raids and (b) the public similarly involved, what has been the medical recovery rate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) This type of information is not available from any source within this portfolio. It is not possible to establish from Medicare data whether or not a claim is for a stress related condition, and certainly not what specific circumstances may have caused the condition. The Health Insurance Commission is not privy to clinical information in the routine processing of Medicare claims.
